item.title: There‚Äôs Hope Pok√©mon TCG 30th Anniversary Cards Will Include Reprints Of All-Time Classics
item.content:encoded:
When it became obvious there was going to be no new mainline Pok√©mon game in 2025, it raised a huge question about what would happen to the Pok√©mon TCG. The three-yearly cycle had become so normal that the card game was built around it, releasing sets themed around the new monsters and mechanics added to each new gaming entry, so what would it do when that was taken away? The answer, it turned out, was the revival of Mega Evolution, loosely tied into the events of Pok√©mon Z-A, but mostly just doing its own nostalgic thing. But now we know that Pok√©mon Winds and Waves won‚Äôt be out until 2027! So what then? Step forward, the 30th Anniversary Set.

During the 30th anniversary Pok√©mon Presents, among its lacking assortment of announcements, there was a brief appearance of the TCG‚Äîalbeit a very opaque one. The one solid piece of information we received was that the new cards will‚Äîfor the first time ever‚Äîrelease simultaneously worldwide. Cards are usually released in Japan first, in the country‚Äôs own bespoke sets, and then repurposed for the rest of the world in differently arranged and titled collections.

The minute-long inclusion showed a range of favorite cards from the last 30 years, often in non-English versions, before faux-interrupting itself to reveal Mew and Mewtwo seemingly on some sort of LSD trip. But nothing tangible, nothing we could infer. Could it be the case that this wasn‚Äôt a gallery of old faves, but potentially cards that will be included in the new sets?

That‚Äôs what‚Äôs being claimed by some sites, like Wargamer, convinced that the cards shown will be part of this celebratory series of sets. And you can see why, given the clip is so infuriatingly uninformative, and especially the choice to show the classic cards in very many different languages, and then finishing on the news that it will release simultaneously worldwide. It seems to speak to this international approach.

I‚Äôm not convinced. I think the intention here was to fly through the TCG‚Äôs 30-year history, given the cards appeared in chronological order, beginning with that classic Chonkachu #58 and the infamous holo Charizard from the Base Set (although here shown as Glurak, its German name), before jumping to a French Palkia Lv. X from Diamond & Pearl‚Äòs Great Encounters and a Japanese Lugia from Wind from the Sea (2008 and 2002 respectively). We then get a Spanish Uxie Lv. 55 from Legends Awakened (also 2008), followed by the briefest glimpse of both halves of the Darkrai & Cresselia Legend from HS Triumphant (2010), a Genesect EX from 2013‚Äôs Pok√©mon Blast, and a Chinese Solgaleo GX (2017 for the English version). Finally there‚Äôs a burst of four: Pikachu & Zekrom‚Äôs Tagteam from 2019‚Äôs Team Up in Thai, Zacian V from 2020‚Äôs Sword & Shield base set in Korean, Arceus VSTAR from 2022‚Äôs Brilliant Stars in Indonesian, and finally a silver-edged Amazing Rare Raikou from Pok√©mon‚Äôs 2020 arrival in Chinese.

The only oddity in there is that Chinese Solgaleo GX, as at that point the game hadn‚Äôt launched in China. It was, however, released as part of the Chinese Storming Emergence Radiant set in 2022, making it a really weird pick for this montage. My suspicion is less that this is an indication of a new version of the card, and more that someone made a cock-up.

There is of course precedent for re-releasing classic cards as part of an anniversary collection. For the 25th birthday in 2021, Celebrations was released which included the 25-card Classic Collection featuring reprints of various cards from the previous years, marked by a Pikachu head. Then there was 2016‚Äôs XY Evolutions that was primarily made up of reprints of Base Set cards, infuriatingly similar to the originals but for a tiny set symbol. So, yeah, it‚Äôs entirely possible.

We‚Äôve reached out to Pok√©mon to see if we can get any clarification, but given PokeBeach is claiming the sets won‚Äôt start releasing until October of this year, it seems likely the company will keep quiet about it until nearer the end of this Mega Evolutions era.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-tcg-30th-anniversary-set-classic-cards-2000674478

item.title: The Internet Reacts To The First Photo Of Amazon‚Äôs God Of War
item.content:encoded:
Earlier today, Amazon released the first photo from the live-action God of War series starring Ryan Hurst as Kratos and Callum Vinson as Atreus. It didn‚Äôt look great to me. And looking around online, it‚Äôs clear I‚Äôm not alone in thinking this first tease looks bad.

While you can definitely find some positive and neutral online reactions to the image put out by Amazon on Friday, a lot of users on the web seem unconvinced by the first set photo of Kratos and his son. First announced in 2022, the God of War live-action series could end up being great. Perhaps this image is just a bad first impression of the series we‚Äôll get later. That‚Äôs very possible! But it doesn‚Äôt change how meh Kratos in particular looks in this initial photo, which is why so many online pulled out knives and went after it on social media.

pic.twitter.com/pPqgfd3CUX

‚Äî Mikel Ni√±o (@Belegurx) February 27, 2026

Esto lo he visto yo antes en otra parte‚Ä¶ https://t.co/7uDxOiOgw7 pic.twitter.com/KP75bFZoZK

‚Äî RetroFlama (@RetroFlama) February 27, 2026

https://t.co/PnVU0o5ZZu pic.twitter.com/Iu0pmSAUkv

‚Äî aLexBY11 (@aLexBY11) February 27, 2026

Bring him back pic.twitter.com/2WthKKEaG9

‚Äî ItsRichard (@Richyc89) February 27, 2026

First announced in 2022, the God of War live-action series on Amazon doesn‚Äôt have a release date yet. It is expected to arrive in early 2027. It has already received a second season order. Ronald D. Moore is running the show and writing for it. You can read more about who is in it here.



https://kotaku.com/god-of-war-amazon-live-action-image-online-reactions-kratos-atreus-2000674479

item.title: Every Pok√©mon Confirmed For Winds And Waves So Far
item.content:encoded:
Every time a new Pok√©mon game is announced, folks are wondering what returning monsters will make the cut this time. Winds and Waves are coming to Switch 2 next year, and we saw quite a few returning critters on the roster just in the first few minutes of footage Game Freak revealed at today‚Äôs Pok√©mon Presents.

Thus far, the only new Pok√©mon we know of are the three starters: Browt, Pombon, and Gecqua. Other than that, every other monster that was shown in the game thus far originates from the previous generations. As such, we have a pretty good idea of what some of the Pok√©dex is going to look like. Here is a big ol‚Äô list of all the Pok√©mon we know of so far:

  • Brow
  • Pombon
  • Gecqua
  • Pikachu
  • Gloom
  • Tropius
  • Wailmer
  • Wailord
  • Nymble
  • Tailow
  • Tangela
  • Oddish
  • Ledyba
  • Ledian
  • Slugma
  • Sizzlipede 
  • Wingull
  • Krabby
  • Sandygast
  • Corsola
  • Mareanie
  • Toxapex
  • Tympole
  • Carnivine
  • Duskull
  • Lumineon
  • Tynamo
  • Frillish

As those are all seen in the trailer, it‚Äôs likely their evolutions will be in the game as well, assuming they don‚Äôt get some kind of regional variant that changes their evolution line. Those include:

  • Pichu
  • Raichu
  • Vileplume
  • Bellossom
  • Lokix
  • Swellow
  • Tangrowth
  • Macargo
  • Centiskorch 
  • Pelipper
  • Kingler
  • Palossand 
  • Palpitoad
  • Seismitoad
  • Jellicent

Pok√©mon Winds and Waves are coming to Switch 2 next year, meaning there will be a two-year gap between Legends: Z-A, the last RPG in the series which launched in October 2025, and its successor. It doesn‚Äôt sound like Pok√©mon fans will be wanting for things to look forward to in 2026, though, as The Pok√©mon Company is celebrating the franchise‚Äôs 30th anniversary with events and new games like Pokopia and Pok√©mon Champions.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-winds-waves-pokedex-new-old-pikachu-switch-2-2000674490

item.title: Fans Think They May Have Figured Out One Of Pok√©mon Winds And Waves‚Äô Legendaries
item.content:encoded:
After quite a few leaks, Pok√©mon Winds and Waves have finally been officially unveiled today as part of the series‚Äô 30th anniversary. In the first trailer, we saw the games‚Äô starter trio, but otherwise we only saw old monsters that debuted in previous games. However, fans think the few minutes of footage we got may offer a hint about one of the Legendary Pok√©mon we‚Äôll meet when the games launch next year.

In two sections of the trailer, you can see a cloud formation that looks kind of like a dragon. The first time is in the opening cinematic when a trainer is looking through their drawings of Pikachu in various regions. The final image in this section is one of Pikachu looking out a window into Winds and Waves‚Äô ocean region, and you can see the dragon-shaped cloud in the sky. 

Oh hey it appears in the art at the start too pic.twitter.com/RXHtwi1iOY

‚Äî Puppi üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è (@PuppiPoppi) February 27, 2026

Later, in one of the environmental shots, you can see the dragon-shaped cloud prominently in the sky in-game. Given the games‚Äô titles, I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if Winds‚Äô mascot legendary was a flying-type Dragon Pok√©mon and Waves got some kind of sea creature. Some are speculating this is a Gyarados‚Äô silhouette, and while the one in the initial sketch from the beginning of the trailer definitely resembles the Water/Flying monster from Kanto, the one we see in the actual game itself doesn‚Äôt look like it much at all. Could this be a nod to a Pok√©mon we haven‚Äôt met yet? 

However, there might be a different explanation based on Winds and Waves‚Äô leaks. Though it hasn‚Äôt been officially revealed, the games‚Äô equivalent of raid battles will reportedly be signified in the open world by Pok√©mon-shaped clouds. So it‚Äôs possible this might actually be a Gyarados rather than a new monster, but this also doesn‚Äôt preclude it from being a different monster entirely.

Based on the Teraleak, the Pok√©mon shaped clouds are just the new equivalent raid mechanic. pic.twitter.com/xG0gUHfu0H

‚Äî Centro LEAKS (@CentroLeaks) February 27, 2026

Winds and Waves are coming to Switch 2 next year, making them the first exclusive Pok√©mon RPGs on the system. I would‚Äôve expected the original Switch to get at least one more Pok√©mon RPG given how many Switches have been sold in the past nine years, but if you‚Äôre looking for a system seller, the new Pok√©mon games will do it.



https://kotaku.com/pokemon-winds-waves-legendary-cloud-dragon-switch-2-2000674486
